title: Reversible Acute Renal Failure After Cephalothin
abstract: Letters1 August 1975Reversible Acute Renal Failure After CephalothinJOHN E. ENGLE, M.D., JOSEPH DRAGO, M.D., BRUCE CARLIN, M.D., ANTON C. SCHOOLWERTH, M.D.JOHN E. ENGLE, M.D.Search for more papers by this author, JOSEPH DRAGO, M.D.Search for more papers by this author, BRUCE CARLIN, M.D.Search for more papers by this author, ANTON C. SCHOOLWERTH, M.D.Search for more papers by this authorAuthor, Article, and Disclosure Informationhttps://doi.org/10.7326/0003-4819-83-2-232_2 SectionsAboutPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissions ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail ExcerptWe recently treated a patient with oliguric acute renal failure after cephalothin (Keflin®) therapy.This 48-year-old man was referred to the M. S. Hershey Medical Center because of azotemia and oliguria. Twelve days before admission he was admitted to another hospital for right renal colic. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) was 15 mg/dl; an intravenous pyelogram showed a normal left kidney and nonvisualization of the right kidney, with several calcific densities in the area of the right kidney. Because of fever, he was given cephalothin intravenously, 16 g/day for 8 days. On the eighth day of therapy, oliguria was noted,...References1.
